It's fantastic. Even for people unfamiliar with FromSoft's other games, this game is accessible in spite of its lineage of difficulty. There are multiple things you can do to gain strength, and also multiple strategies you can employ within combat itself.The addition of the open world and crafting system is a huge boon to the formula. The open world encourages exploration, which has always been a strong point in FromSoft games, and also opens up tons of opportunities to power up through side activities and explore quests through the various characters you can find and talk to. The crafting system also functions as a way to ease exploration by creating useful tools, as well as make combat more manageable through crafting throwables, ammo, status inflicting items and buffs.The moment to moment gameplay is vastly improved as well. You still have your light and heavy attacks, your guarding and parrying, and your magical spells in two different flavors. But all of these features have improved in a number of ways, including new ways to interact in combat. Combat Arts can be a fundamental part of the way you play, opening up lots of new moves and abilities, the new guard counter allows for a much more defensive playstyle to punish opponents after they attack, and heavy (especially charged heavy) attacks can break your opponents stance to open them up to critical hits. If you're struggling with a fight, changing your strategy can be a viable option, and if that fails then opening up the crafting menu can also give you the edge you need. If all else fails, you can rely on your fellow Tarnished and summon a friend (or stranger) to help you out in multiplayer.This game is the best version released of FromSoft's formula that they've been refining for years. As someone who's played every game in the Souls series, including Bloodborne and Sekiro, this one is my favorite. And here's to hoping the DLC improves on this already great game even more!

This game saved my career as a truck driver. On the night of February 20, 2022 I was called into my boss's office. Larry sat me down on the other side of his desk, at this moment I was quite ecstatic, I thought I was going to get a pay raise for how good I had been doing on the road! Oh boy was I wrong. Larry had told me that I was actually causing a loss of profits for the company and that if I didn't step up my performance soon they would have no choice but to get rid of me. I thought to myself "‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•! I can't lose my job, I'm 57 years old with 10 years of payments left on my mortgage, $15,000 in student loan debt, $50,000 in credit card debt, a wife, 3 kids, 4 dogs, and 2 cats. This might be the end for me." I took the next day off of work to collect myself, and that's when I saw it. I opened up Steam for the first time in months, at the top there was a bright green banner with the beautiful, bold, yellowed letters "ELDEN RING" at the top. Now, as a big fan of the previous hit FromSoftware game "Dark Souls 2" I knew I had to check it out. I was hooked just from the images, don't even get me started about those videos. They put a little pep in my step if you're picking up what I'm putting down. I pre-ordered the game immediately, but I thought to myself "How do I play this on the road?" I knew there was only one option, so I did it. I ordered a Steam Deck to accompany me on my journeys travelling through the blessed lands of freedom. Before I knew it, the Steam Deck had arrived and Elden Ring had been released. I played this game every single night when I was parked in the truck stops. I was in love, for the first time in forever I felt like I enjoyed my job again. I was motivated to get my performance up and save my career. My performance increased by 76% when I started playing Elden Ring and my boss actually ended up giving me a raise. Thank you Miyazaki and FromSoftware for changing my life.

All was right in the world.But sometimes father, he'd have a few beers, and maybe he'd get a little mad at mum for cooking Meatloaf (Again) and you'd sit all quiet while he yells at her, and she hits him and then he looks at you, with that same look he just had for your mother. He grabs you by the arm and punches you in your 8 year old mouth. You sit there stunned, helpless because father always hits you when he and mother yell at each other.Years this goes on until one day you've had enough. You move out of home and go out into the world keen to never look back on these dark times again. Not long after, you've started a family of your own, and you've vowed to never be like your father, you'd always treat your child better then he ever did.Until one day, a messages comes by, "Hi son. This is the part where most fun is to be had.Endgame content is typical, every enemy is overscaled, overpoised, overboosted in every way. In some cases some simple regular enemies have more hitpoints than some midgame bosses. Technically your HP is irrelevant as you are 1-3 hits, depending on your vitality. In some cases, some simpel field mobs are pvp worthy, the invader NPC-s have nothing compared to them. Even bosses can be hardly compared to some. Also, mediocre weapons are hidden in endgame which would be useful in earlier stages, grabbing them simply adds nothing to the gameplay.In many cases the best tactic to use: dash from 1 SG to another, you have your progress saved. Farming is done via boss assisting, item acquisition can be postponed. You won't use most of them anyway in bossfights.Also when a game has pixelperfect platforming integrated instantly looses 3 points in my eyes.All in all not a bad game but the endgame technically kills the part to which try to aim.Tho Malenia is cool.

I get it, another Elden Ring review that is negative that is unfounded but just giving my feedback.The mandatory, I have played Demon Souls, all of the Dark Souls games, Sekiro Armored Core 6 (I know its not Souls but its awesome!).I like the tighter experience of previous titles, smaller, interconnected, filled with purpose.I felt Elden Ring was just a big world with dumb mobs placed every where, dungeons that felt so samey, reskinned bosses, and just crap tons of stuff to get into. For me it was a grind to just get through it.I guess I have gotten older and want to play whats fun not whats trendy, it just wasnt for me. I am not a combat efficientato by any means and the options, spells, ashes of war, summons were all good systems. At its core though, for ME, its just tiresome. Why or how can poison go through a wall? Why can a bad guy plunge his axe through rock and hit you on the other side? Why do bosses have unlimited stamina? Elden Ring had some of the most aggressive boss battles I have ever played through in a From Software game. Hands down. The last section of the game is littered with them back to back to back, its insane. Granted the open world gives opportunities to gain some flasks back but thats so you dont have to go back to a spot to heal again, it didnt make it more accepting in terms of difficulty. The dungeons generally are filled with the same wolves, pots, and gremlins, with a few traps and a boss or two at the end of it. Once you get the goodies in the dungeon or cave you usually find yourself dead at the bosses door or near death with no flasks forcing you to death with the boss so that you can just run all the way to the door again if there was no stake to bring you back to near the door. Fighting on the horse was fun although, the farther you get into the game, the more you realize the horse is just another piece of armor that most enemies are going to be able to kill. Its fast but they are faster.I think for people who love this genre and the Souls franchise this is a dream come true. Its a big expansive world with enough variety for people who want to see it, and lots of things to explore. More mini bosses, more dungeons, more exploration, more armor/weapons, summons, just more more more. But its also just more frustration, cheap boss battles and the forever present git gud nastiness of the community when it comes to giving feedback.

Granted the open world gives opportunities to gain some flasks back but thats so you dont have to go back to a spot to heal again, it didnt make it more accepting in terms of difficulty. The dungeons generally are filled with the same wolves, pots, and gremlins, with a few traps and a boss or two at the end of it. Once you get the goodies in the dungeon or cave you usually find yourself dead at the bosses door or near death with no flasks forcing you to death with the boss so that you can just run all the way to the door again if there was no stake to bring you back to near the door. Fighting on the horse was fun although, the farther you get into the game, the more you realize the horse is just another piece of armor that most enemies are going to be able to kill. Its fast but they are faster.I think for people who love this genre and the Souls franchise this is a dream come true. Its a big expansive world with enough variety for people who want to see it, and lots of things to explore. More mini bosses, more dungeons, more exploration, more armor/weapons, summons, just more more more. But its also just more frustration, cheap boss battles and the forever present git gud nastiness of the community when it comes to giving feedback.
